But we all took it harder than she did. And
before we had

1176.97.text:
even let the dust settle, she was saying,
We're gonna do this again in 2002. And I remember

1180.26.text:
thinking, Ee,
I don't know. But of course, I was onboard

1184.03.text:
You weren't following the playbook of most
public relations executives. You were following

1189.62.text:
your
mind and, to some extent, your heart.

1191.59.text:
Yeah. You know, I believe in that, because
I think a lot of executives, if they can,

1196.02.text:
they do that. And I
just feel even when it's a learning experience,

1202.01.text:
having the experience makes me better overall.
And that

1205.16.text:
was a learning experience. And oh, gosh, in
2002, we pulled it off, and that was interesting.

1211.93.text:
And that
was the other thing, kind of still in naïveté,

1214.94.text:
not having been in politics, it was like,
Okay, we're done, I

1216.85.text:
can go back to my life. And I remember Linda
called and she said, You know, I think you

1222.30.text:
would be one
of the people I want to recommend for Board

1224.30.text:
of Regents. And I remember saying, Oh, why
that? I mean,

1229.83.text:
She had to talk me into it. And it was my
alma mater, it was something that sounded

1237.51.text:
interesting. And
that was another journey. But I thought we

1240.20.text:
were done. So, that was the first lesson;
you're not done

1244.43.text:
That was such an interesting chapter in your
life. For those of watching as well. I remember

1250.08.text:
thinking, you know, what you got into was
a mire with the president of the University,

1257.03.text:
And a very slippery situation. And your expertise
is public relations, but it was very hard

1266.27.text:
Yeah; and it's hard to be in it and manage
something. I know that.

1269.02.text: And as the chair of the Board of Regents.

1270.93.text:
I mean, I think there was a perception at
some time that you were bungling it.

1274.51.text:
Yeah; yeah. I actually thought it was. I knew
it was bungled, but I also had the perspective

1281.34.text:
of there was a
whole bunch of stuff. You know, it was an

1285.08.text:
employee-employer relationship between the
Board and Evan.

1288.86.text:
And there are certain laws you have to follow,
confidentiality and things. So, we were not

1295.45.text:
in a position to
say, Hey, we tried this, we did this. And

1299.18.text:
I think the employee can say whatever they
want pretty much,

1302.33.text:
really. And you see that over and over. So,
that was a disadvantage, and it was hard.

1307.36.text:
The other part was,
you know, you will never know the effort we

1311.29.text:
made to do it carefully. And the sense, I
think, that was

1315.24.text:
there was that, I have this contract, no way
you're gonna get me out of it, and I'm not

1319.85.text:
going anywhere.
And as time went on, I think it became clear

1323.51.text:
the University was suffering, and we had to
do something.

1326.53.text:
And in fact, our creditors told us that. And
it felt very bungled. It felt like there were

1332.98.text:
lots of pieces that
you couldn't control. It was horrible watching

1336.86.text:
the public perception of it, and knowing there
was another

1341.56.text:
story, but you can't be the one to tell it.
You're the employer.

1344.27.text: I recall the Kaleo O University.

1350.77.text:
Their banner headline, the student newspaper
said, Bad Kitty.

1357.14.text:
So, that had to be a low point in general
when people were saying, What are they doing

1362.38.text:
over there,
can't they get their act together on the Board

1366.44.text:
It was a low point in terms of not being able
to do anything about it.

1368.70.text:
Especially since you were used to the other
party, in your view, bungling it. And then

1374.47.text:
Yeah; absolutely. That was really rugged;
that was really rugged, I think for all of

1377.47.text:
us. And yet, I found
the decision we made to be the right one.

1381.43.text:
I've never regretted that decision. How it
unfolded and what it

1385.24.text:
looked like on the outside; yeah, there was
a lot of regret about that, but not the decision.

1390.04.text:
And I don't
think any of us did.

1391.93.text:
The right outcome; and it really was. You
know, that's the decision. I mean, there were

1395.54.text:
regents who quit
because they didn't want to go down. They

1397.80.text:
knew what needed to be done, but they didn't
want to be in

1400.13.text:
the middle of all that. And there were some
amazing people who stuck around and said,

1404.53.text:
This needs to be
done for the good of our university. And I

1406.87.text:
think there is some vindication in what happened
at Westfield

1410.75.text:
Many times, especially over politics, you
felt, no doubt, uncomfortable.

1417.63.text:
You know, I've never found discomfort to be
an inhibiting factor.

1422.19.text:
I'm sure you had some sleepless nights over
the regents matter.

1425.63.text:
Many; I think I didn't sleep for like a whole
year. I think that's what you call political

1428.96.text:
courage. I call it
that when I see it in other people. And when

1431.85.text:
you're in it, it doesn't feel like any kind
of courage; it feels

1433.94.text:
like a nightmare. But in the end, if something
good came out or a group of people were able

1438.98.text:
to come
together to make something happen that was

1441.60.text:
right or needed to happen, or bigger than
they could do on

1446.21.text:
Yeah; it does. I failed in '98. Do you know
how many people wouldn't even talk to me after

1450.05.text:
'98? She's
the one who went to the other side, you know.

1455.42.text:
It sounds like you've been able to do what
you want to, what you feel strongly about,

1460.03.text:
and not really
suffer too much for it in business or personally.

1464.31.text:
I mean, I don't know if somebody may be out
there trying to get me, but I'm still here,

1469.10.text:
and I'm probably
not even aware of most of the time. And what

1472.65.text:
I am aware of is that I have a whole lot of
folks in the

1475.64.text:
community I love working with, I have fabulous
clients and a team that I work with day-to-day.

1480.16.text:
I pretty
much wake up enthusiastic and say, I want

1484.75.text:
to go make this happen today. And so far,
nobody's stopped

1489.64.text:
From riding motorcycles, to fighting for her
child's life, to risking her reputation, to

1495.20.text:
making
difficult decisions, Kitty Lagareta has shown

1498.16.text:
herself to be a risk-taker and a fighter.
Mahalo to

1501.66.text:
Kitty Lagareta of Honolulu, and mahalo to
you for joining us. For PBS Hawaii and Long

1508.08.text:
Story
Short, I'm Leslie Wilcox. A hui hou.

1531.57.text:
I started skateboarding when I was nine with
those little metal wheels, and I thought it

1535.90.text:
was the most
exhilarating thing ever, and I just loved

1539.38.text:
it. And I continued doing it past my first
child being born, and

1544.70.text:
then I used to skateboard with my sons. I
remember we were at Manoa Elementary School,

1550.49.text:
and there was
a big driveway down to the school, and we

1552.71.text:
were going down it, and it had a lot of loose
gravel. And I

1556.06.text:
was about forty-three and my sons were, you
know, older. Anyway, I hit the bottom, and

1560.37.text:
I was so excited
that I'd made it down that I put my foot down,

1564.24.text:
and I went sliding across the gravel, and
just took all the

1567.41.text:
skin off. And I had to go to the doctor to
get cleaned up. He goes, You know, a woman

1571.94.text:
in her forties has
no business skateboarding. And so, I kinda

1575.06.text:
took that to heart, but when I turned fifty,
I started again.

1577.35.text:
[CHUCKLE] Do you remember saying this? There's
nothing quite like rolling along with the

1582.72.text:
wind
blowing by, not sure if you're going to crash.

1585.66.text:
Yeah; that's sort of my motto, my life experience,
yes. Yeah. There's something about kind of

1591.69.text:
pushing
the edge. I think if you can keep that feeling

1596.45.text:
you had as a kid in some of your life day-to-day,
those are

1600.03.text:
things that felt good then, and they still
feel good.
